title: 107_hr4514
content: The Act titled "Veterans' Major Medical Facilities Construction Act of 2002" authorizes major medical facility projects. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out major medical facility projects for seismic corrections and clinical improvements in various locations in California, with specified amounts allocated for each project. The Department of Veterans Affairs is undertaking various projects across different states, including seismic correction in San Diego, California ($47.1 million), ambulatory surgery in Cleveland, Ohio ($32.5 million), health office consolidation in Anchorage, Alaska ($59 million), ward renovation in West Haven, Connecticut ($15.3 million), and ambulatory care expansion in Tampa, Florida ($18.23 million). The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to lease a Satellite Outpatient Clinic in Charlotte, North Carolina for up to $2,626,000. Authorization of appropriations is also granted. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2003 includes $285,000,000 for Construction, Major Projects, and $2,626,000 for a medical care lease. Projects in section 2 must use funds from 2003 appropriations, previous year's funds, or non-specific project funds. SEC. 5 increases the threshold for major medical facility construction projects from $4,000,000 to $6,000,000. The amendment applies to Department of Veterans Affairs projects funded after October 1, 2002. SEC. 6 outlines criteria for minor construction projects. Section 8103 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include new subsection (e) which specifies the purpose of minor construction projects for medical facilities. Projects should focus on seismic and fire safety improvements, utility systems upgrades, and accommodations for persons with disabilities. Improved accommodation for persons with disabilities, specialized programs at patient care facilities including blind rehabilitation centers, programs for mentally ill veterans, substance-use disorder programs, physical medicine and rehabilitation activities, long-term care facilities, and amputation care facilities. The curr_chunk focuses on specific healthcare services for veterans, including amputation care, spinal cord injury centers, traumatic brain injury programs, women veterans' health programs, and facilities for hospice and palliative care programs. Passed the House of Representatives on May 21, 2002.
